reviews.reviewText:
Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport is truly one of the best airports in the country. As one of the busiest airports in India, it handles the high volume of passengers with remarkable efficiency. The facilities inside are top-notch, offering everything from luxury lounges and diverse dining options to seamless check-in and baggage services.

The architecture of the airport is absolutely stunning, blending modern design with cultural elements that reflect the spirit of Mumbai. The moment you step in, you feel the grandeur and meticulous planning that has gone into every detail.

Getting to the airport is also a smooth experience. The roads leading from the highway are clean, well-maintained, and clearly marked. It‚Äôs all very well-organized, making the journey stress-free from start to finish.

Parking is another plus ‚Äî there‚Äôs a huge space available, which is well-managed and easily accessible.

Overall, Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport sets a high standard for airports across the country and is a true gateway to Mumbai‚Äôs vibrant energy.

Shining example of functionality and aesthetics.
The moment you step in the check in hall, you're greeted by a stunning 3d model of terminal. The ceiling itself is a masterpiece, with it's iconic pattern that adds a sense of grandeur and elegance to the space.
Washrooms are well kept, beautifully arranged green planters at several locations. Charging points are strategically placed and come with convenient shelves to securely hold your mobile, such smaller details make a big difference for travelers.
Experience doesn't end at arrival either. Baggage reclaim hall are also adorned with beautiful art works, to reflect India's rich cultural heritage, making even the wait for your luggage a visually engaging experience.

It's one of the few Airports with connectivity to almost all major & small airports across the country.

Beyond connectivity, the airport is a shining example of how functionality can blend seamlessly with aesthetics.
The food court overlooking the runway is a unique highlight. You can sip a hot coffee while watching the flights take off, land, and park.
Even the area of conveyer belts are thoughtfully designed, making the visual experience pleasent.

Reaching  and moving out of the airport is hassle free. Multiple options like the Metro, BEST Buses, Taxis etc and more.

üí°IF you are arriving for departure, start early. It's safe to reach 3 hours prior to avoid any last minute rush.

Very beautiful place, I spent about four hours here. The place is very beautiful and I spent all my time looking around. I enjoyed the food and drinks on the beautiful facilities here. And the toilet, bathroom, everything was available, but the crowd of people was a little too much. It was quite nice to spend time here. There were many people walking around in front of your eyes, everyone was busy with their work. But it was really very nice.

Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (CSMIA), Mumbai, is India‚Äôs second-busiest airport and a major international gateway. Located in Santacruz, about 8 km from South Mumbai, it handles over 50 million passengers annually. The airport has two terminals: Terminal 1 (T1) for domestic flights (primarily low-cost carriers) and Terminal 2 (T2) for international and full-service domestic flights.

Key Features & Facilities
T2‚Äôs Grand Architecture: Known for its stunning design, T2 features the "Jaya He" Museum, a 3-km-long art wall showcasing Indian heritage.

Dining & Shopping: A wide range of restaurants, cafes, and luxury retail stores (including duty-free).

Lounges: Premium lounges like the Air India Maharaja Lounge and Plaza Premium Lounge for business class passengers and paid access.

Connectivity: Free Wi-Fi (limited duration), ample charging points, and business centers.

Transport Options: Prepaid taxis, app-based cabs (Uber/Ola), and BEST buses. The Mumbai Metro (Line 2A) connects to the city.

Tips for Travelers
Early Arrival: Due to heavy crowds, arrive 3 hours before international flights and 2 hours before domestic flights.

Security: Separate queues for passengers with only hand baggage (fast track).

The airport is huge with good number of gates and washrooms at regular distance. The airport has lots of eateries. Unfortunately, these restaurants are exorbitantly costly. On the other hand, there is wonderful lounge by Adani is an excellent option. The toilets are clean whereas there is a smoker zone too. There are well placed signs that make it convenient to move around. The only downside is that the water outlets should be more and easily visible.

This airport is terminal 2 airport which is approx 5 km far from terminal 1. Plz note that indigo domstic flight numbers starting with number 6 is usually depart from this terminal when it is a connectinv flight. Both skybridge and bus service are available while boarding flight. For transfer from terminal 1 to terminal 2 you can get free bus service. Just going outside of domestic portion of Terminal 1 you have to go right and you will see the bus stand. Just show your boarding pass and you will be elligible for free bus ride to terminal 2. I found domestic area of  terminal 2 is quite bigger than terminal 1. It is much decorated and looks very beautiful at night. Travel lounge is also available named as Adani lounge which is very spacious. There is also smoke zone in terminal 2. The terminal 2 is moderately clean  and it is very crowded terminal. I saw birds inside the terminal, mostly piegeon inside the airport near securty check area. Please note, even for domestic travel and luggage pick up at last destination airport, when your connecting flight is from terminal 2, you have to go through again security check.

üõ´ My Best Experience at Mumbai International Airport While Traveling to Delhi üåü

My journey from Mumbai Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (CSMIA) to Delhi was not just a travel plan but a wonderful experience in itself. Known as one of the busiest and most stylish airports in India, Mumbai International Airport truly gave me a perfect blend of comfort, modernity, and excitement before boarding my flight to Delhi.

‚ú® First Impression ‚Äì A World-Class Airport
The moment I entered the terminal, I was amazed by the architecture and the artistic designs. The ceilings, wall patterns, and overall ambiance reflected a unique cultural touch while maintaining a modern international standard. The airport staff was helpful right from the entrance, guiding passengers and ensuring everything was smooth and well-organized.

üß≥ Check-In & Security Made Easy
The check-in counters were clearly arranged, and even though there was a huge crowd of travelers, the process moved quickly. I used the baggage drop facility and was happy with how efficiently the staff managed everything. Security checks were systematic, and the polite behavior of officers made me feel safe and comfortable.

‚òï Food & Relaxation at Its Best
Before boarding, I explored the food court and lounges. Mumbai Airport offers a wide variety of options, from Indian street food flavors to international cuisines. I enjoyed a hot cup of coffee along with some snacks, which made the waiting time pleasant. The seating area was cozy and clean, allowing me to relax and watch the flights take off and land.

üõçÔ∏è Shopping Experience
The duty-free and retail shops were another highlight of my journey. From luxury brands to local handicrafts, the shops had everything a traveler could wish for. It almost felt like being in a shopping mall inside the airport. Browsing through these stores kept me engaged and added more charm to my travel experience.

üõ´ Boarding & Flight to Delhi
Boarding was organized, and announcements were clear. The airline staff managed passengers with care, making sure everything moved smoothly. As I walked towards the aircraft, I admired the runway lights and the beautiful view of the airport at night. Taking off from Mumbai gave me that thrilling feeling of adventure as I headed to Delhi.

üåü Final Thought
Overall, my experience at Mumbai International Airport was extraordinary. The blend of modern facilities, cultural design, world-class services, and smooth travel management made my journey truly memorable. It wasn‚Äôt just about flying to Delhi, but about enjoying every step of the travel experience starting right from Mumbai.

A world away from the glittering clubs and high rises of Mumbai, this region is underlined with brightly-coloured homes, narrow streets, and the flurry of fishermen going about their day, locals passing by, and children enjoying a game of street cricket. The village has been around for over 800 years, and the Koli people will take you through their unique way of life that‚Äôs remained unaltered through this time.

The skyline is, without a doubt, the highlight of dining at Dome, offering a truly spectacular setting. However, I was rather disappointed with a few aspects of the experience.

Firstly, the immaturity of the serving staff was noticeable. Managing the staff in general proved to be quite challenging, but my server, in particular, was difficult to deal with. It gave the impression of a clear lack of professionalism, which detracted from the overall dining experience.

Secondly, we ordered a number of drinks, including some cocktails, and one in particular was quite underwhelming. Given the price point, I had expected far better. In hindsight, I would rather try the Taj next time.

Lastly, the selection of snacks was quite disappointing, particularly for vegetarians and vegans, as there were no suitable options available. For a venue of this calibre, one would have expected a more thoughtfully curated menu.

While the setting is undoubtedly stunning, the experience itself left much to be desired.

Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus (CSMT), formerly known as Victoria Terminus, is a historic railway station in Mumbai, India. Completed in 1888, it showcases a blend of Victorian Gothic Revival and traditional Indian architectural styles. In 2004, UNESCO recognized its cultural significance by designating it a World Heritage Site.

The station's architecture is notable for its intricate stone carvings, pointed arches, and a central dome reminiscent of traditional Indian palaces. The interior features high ceilings, spacious halls, and stained-glass windows, reflecting the grandeur of its era. Recent restoration efforts have aimed to preserve these architectural details, ensuring the station remains a visual delight for visitors.

As one of India's busiest railway stations, CSMT serves as a crucial hub for both long-distance and suburban trains, operating 24 hours a day and accommodating millions of passengers annually. The station is equipped with essential amenities, including waiting rooms, restrooms, and food stalls. However, during peak hours, the station can become exceedingly crowded, which may be overwhelming for some travelers.

Visitors often praise CSMT for its architectural beauty and historical significance. Standing across the road provides a vantage point to appreciate the building's grandeur, though the surrounding hustle and bustle can be distracting. Inside, the station's operational efficiency is notable, but the sheer volume of commuters can lead to congestion, particularly during rush hours. It's advisable to remain vigilant and mindful of personal belongings due to the dense crowds.

Beyond its architectural and functional roles, CSMT holds a special place in Mumbai's cultural landscape. It has been featured in various films and is often associated with the city's colonial past and its evolution into a modern metropolis. The station's presence contributes to Mumbai's identity, symbolizing a blend of history and progress.

Despite its grandeur, CSMT faces several challenges. The station's location in a high-traffic area contributes to significant air pollution, which poses risks to both the structure and the health of commuters. Additionally, the overwhelming crowds during peak hours can be a deterrent for some visitors, making navigation through the station challenging.

Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus is more than just a railway station; it's a monument that encapsulates Mumbai's rich history and architectural heritage. While its beauty and significance are undeniable, potential visitors should be prepared for the challenges posed by large crowds and the fast-paced environment typical of a major urban transit hub. For those interested in architecture and history, a visit to CSMT offers a rewarding glimpse into Mumbai's past and present.

Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus (CSMT), formerly known as Victoria Terminus, is a must-visit landmark in Mumbai and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Built in 1887, this iconic railway station is renowned for its stunning Victorian Gothic Revival architecture blended with traditional Indian elements. Designed by British architect Frederick William Stevens, the station features intricate stone carvings, stained glass windows, domes, turrets, and high arches that showcase the grandeur of colonial-era craftsmanship. Widely regarded as one of the most beautiful railway stations in India, CSMT is not only a major transport hub but also a symbol of Mumbai‚Äôs rich historical and architectural heritage. The station is especially captivating in the evening when it is illuminated, offering a spectacular view for visitors and photographers alike.

One of the class Terminal in Mumbai. People come to Mumbai & arriving here to explore possibilities of their life. One of the ancient & British Era station. The beautiful designs, well disciplined Management of Central Railway to accommodate people & their travel destination. The station is very big, well managed, clean & must visit places in Mumbai.
I went on a heritage walk organised by Raconteur tours and the station and the museum was so beautiful!! The architecture, the history and the majestic appearance was amazing!!

Visiting Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus (CSMT) in Mumbai was an absolutely delightful experience! From the moment I stepped onto the premises, I was in awe of the stunning architecture and the historical grandeur of the station. The beautiful Victorian Gothic design, with intricate carvings, domes, and arches, makes CSMT feel more like a royal palace than a railway station.

The station is not only visually breathtaking but also incredibly well-organized and efficiently managed, considering the huge number of passengers that pass through daily. Despite the hustle and bustle, everything runs smoothly ‚Äì from announcements to cleanliness and security arrangements. I noticed that the platforms were regularly cleaned, and there were ample dustbins, signage, and help desks available to guide travelers.

One of the things I loved the most was how CSMT seamlessly blends history with modernity. The station proudly retains its heritage charm, while also providing modern facilities such as food courts, digital ticket kiosks, clean waiting rooms, and escalators. The lighting at night makes the entire building glow like a piece of art, attracting tourists and photographers alike.

Staff at the station were polite and helpful, which made navigating the station and boarding the train easy and stress-free. The local connectivity from CSMT is also top-notch, with local trains, buses, taxis, and metros easily accessible.

Overall, Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus is more than just a transport hub ‚Äì it‚Äôs a symbol of Mumbai‚Äôs spirit, history, and efficiency. I came away with not just travel memories but also deep admiration for this iconic landmark. Highly recommended for anyone visiting Mumbai ‚Äì whether you‚Äôre catching a train or simply soaking in the architectural brilliance!

Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminal  is one of the best railway stations in India which is located at the very last and it is a place that many people visit. I also came here last time. Many years ago and I want to come here again in the coming time. I love Mumbai very much and I am very eager to come to Mumbai once again so that I can see Mumbai again and can take some selfies or visit Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminal again.

Beautiful station.
But the railway police are very rude.

placeMetadata.name: Mani Bhavan Gandhi Sangrahalaya

sources.snippet: The Mani Bhavan Gandhi Sangrahalaya in Mumbai happens to be a museum where Mahatma Gandhi stayed in the course of his visits to Bombay from the year 1917 to the year 1934. He used to come to Bombay frequently at that time to formulate his very own philosophy of non-violence protest against the ruling Britishers in India. The civil Disobedience Campaign that flagged off in the past was kick-started from this place.
sources.shortName: 55 Places to Visit in Mumbai 2024, Tourist Places & Attractions

sources.snippet: Mani Bhavan Gandhi Sangrahalaya stands as a testament to the enduring legacy of Mahatma Gandhi, offering a glimpse into his life and teachings. The monument has an essence of Gandhi‚Äôs principles of truth, non-violence, and simplicity. The museum houses a treasure of artefacts, including photographs, letters, and personal belongings of Gandhi.
sources.shortName: 51 Best Tourist Places to Visit in Mumbai in 2024 ‚úîLocation to Go

placeMetadata.description: Highlighting Gandhi's life, this home features his room, a library, photos, films & other displays.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Mani Bhavan Gandhi Sangrahalaya is a significant historical site in Mumbai, India. It was Mahatma Gandhi's headquarters from 1917 to 1934 and has been transformed into a museum and research center. The two-story building features Gandhi's room, a library with around 40,000 books, photos, films, paintings, press clippings, and some of his personal belongings.
placeMetadata.address: Mani Bhavan, 19, Laburnum Rd, Babulnath, Gamdevi, Mumbai, Maharashtra 400007, India

reviews.reviewText:
Mani Bhavan in Mumbai was a fascinating and humbling place to visit. This historic building served as Mahatma Gandhi‚Äôs residence and workspace whenever he was in Mumbai, and it played a significant role in India‚Äôs independence movement. Walking through the house, I could almost feel the weight of history‚Äîthe place where Gandhi planned protests, led movements, and inspired millions.

The museum itself was well-organized, with photographs, letters, and artifacts that provided insight into his life and work. One of the highlights was the room where he stayed, preserved exactly as he left it, with his spinning wheel and personal belongings. The library was also impressive, containing a vast collection of books on Gandhi and his philosophy of nonviolence.

What stood out the most was the quiet, reflective atmosphere. Despite being in the heart of bustling Mumbai, Mani Bhavan felt peaceful‚Äîa fitting tribute to a man who preached simplicity and peace. It‚Äôs a must-visit for anyone interested in history, offering a deeper understanding of Gandhi‚Äôs legacy and India‚Äôs struggle for independence.

Mani Bhavan Gandhi Museum in Mumbai is a small yet deeply inspiring place that offers a glimpse into Mahatma Gandhi‚Äôs life and work. It was his headquarters during the freedom movement from 1917 to 1934. The museum houses photographs, letters, and personal belongings, along with a library and a room preserved just as he left it. It's a peaceful, thought-provoking visit for anyone interested in India‚Äôs history and Gandhi‚Äôs legacy. Definitely worth a short stop while exploring Mumbai.

Mani Bhavan in Mumbai is a highly valuable educational museum dedicated to Mahatma Gandhi. It excels at providing comprehensive insights into his life, historical context of the freedom struggle, and Gandhian principles through exhibits, a vast library, and knowledgeable staff. While offering excellent educational programs, some feedback suggests minor improvements in modern presentation and accessibility. Overall, it's an inspiring and essential learning destination.For children, it's a valuable opportunity to learn about a pivotal figure in history and important universal values, provided the visit is structured and explained in an age-appropriate manner.
Definitely worth a visit on a tour of Mumbai. It was well laid out over 3 floors with the top being most interesting with dioramas of Gandhi's life and legacy explained well.

It is an original historical place with artefacts. To be here like breath and see the same as Mahatma, Ali Jinhna, Neru, and many other most important for Indian independence persons. There is the original Gandhi library also.

Great, beautiful, well maintained, place in Gamdevi, beautifully explaining the role of Mahatma Gandhi ji in helping developing and protecting India.
Kids will definitely learn.

Good for the people who have interest in history and art and culture....they have wheelchair option too..have audio guidance giving one üéß but better to use it if you have whole day time and need detail description..
Overall ok for one time visit

Mani Bhavan, hallowed memorial, has association with Gandhi ji of almost two decades. It's a treasure for people looking to explore his world. With Gandhi ji, Mani Bhavan was at the forefront of freedom struggle.
Three floors of Mani Bhavan has endless stories to tell. The ground floor is basically a library having a rich collection of books by and on Gandhiji apart from some mementos. First floor is pictorial journey to Gandhiji's life and events. There is also an auditorium on second floor but it was closed on the day of my visit. On the second floor is the room used by Gandhiji and it is supposedly preserved in it's original settings. There is a diorama gallery, 28 of them giving glimpses to his world. AND the Balcony, where he used to address, the balcony where you can feel his aura even today. The entry on terrace was not allowed on the day of my visit.
With it's abundance, I wonder, what will Mani Bhavan say if it could speak. Will it say something about the enthusiastic student who learnt carding here? Or may be about the scholar who started or took over weeklies and journals like Satyagrahi, Young India and Navjeevan. Or the story of its frustrated resident returning back from Second Round Table Conference. Or may be about Maa Bharti's favourite son's struggle for her freedom, the satyagrah against Rowlatt act, Indian Press Act, his decision to organise bonfire of foreign clothes or launch of civil disobedience movement.
Or may be it will choose to stay silent, even about the apathy of our current generation. For my approximately two hour stay, Mani Bhavan had almost 50 visitors, hardly half a dozen of them were from India. For me, It's a MUST VISIT.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Mumbai, the city that never sleeps, is a vibrant tapestry of culture, history, and stunning landscapes. From the iconic Gateway of India, standing tall against the backdrop of the Arabian Sea, to the serene beauty of the Hanging Gardens perched atop Malabar Hill, this metropolis offers countless opportunities for capturing unforgettable moments. Whether you're wandering through the bustling streets of Bandra or exploring the ancient Kanheri Caves nestled within lush greenery, each corner of Mumbai tells a unique story waiting to be photographed.

As you embark on your photographic journey through this dynamic city, you'll discover a delightful mix of well-known landmarks and hidden gems. Picture yourself at the picturesque Juhu Beach, where the sun dips below the horizon, casting a golden glow over the sandy shores. Or imagine the intricate details of the Rajabai Clock Tower, reminiscent of London's Big Ben, standing proudly amidst the urban hustle. With so many captivating sights to explore, grab your camera and get ready to uncover the best photo spots that Mumbai has to offer!
